[[File:Water-conservation-stamp-1960.jpg|thumb|right|United States 1960 postal stamp advocating water conservation.]]
'''Water conservation''' includes all the policies, strategies and activities to [[sustainably]] manage the [[natural resource]] of [[fresh water]], to protect the [[hydrosphere]], and to meet the current and future human [[demand]]. Population, household size, and growth and affluence all affect how much water is used. Factors such as [[climate change]] have increased pressures on natural water resources especially in [[manufacturing]] and agricultural [[irrigation]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.defra.gov.uk/environment/quality/water/conserve/|title=Water conservation « Defra |work=defra.gov.uk |year=2013 |accessdate=January 24, 2013}}</ref> Many US cities have already implemented policies aimed at water conservation, with much success.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www3.epa.gov/watersense/docs/utilityconservation_508.pdf|title=Cases in Water Conservation: How Efficiency Programs Help Water Utilities Save Water and Avoid Costs|last=|first=|date=|website=EPA.gov|publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency|access-date=}}</ref>
The goals of water conservation efforts include: * Ensuring [[water resources|availability of water]] for future generations where the withdrawal of [[freshwater]] from an [[ecosystem]] does not exceed its natural replacement rate. * [[Energy conservation]] as water pumping, delivery and [[wastewater treatment]] facilities consume a significant amount of energy. In some regions of the world over 15% of total [[electricity consumption]] is devoted to [[water management]]. * [[Habitat conservation]] where minimizing human water use helps to preserve [[freshwater habitat]]s for local wildlife and migrating [[waterfowl]], but also [[water quality]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hermoso |first1=Virgilio |last2=Abell |first2=Robin |last3=Linke |first3=Simon |last4=Boon |first4=Philip |title=The role of protected areas for freshwater biodiversity conservation: challenges and opportunities in a rapidly changing world |journal=Aquatic Conservation: Marine and Freshwater Ecosystems |date=2016 |volume=26 |issue=S1 |pages=3–11 |doi=10.1002/aqc.2681|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/aqc.2681/pdf}}</ref>
==Strategies==
The key activities that benefit water conservation(save water) are as follows: #Any beneficial reduction in [[Drying|water loss]], use and waste of resources.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Duane D. Baumann|author2=John J. Boland|author3=John H. Sims|date=April 1984|title=Water Conservation: The Struggle over Definition|journal=Water Resources Research|volume=20|pages=428–434|url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/WR020i004p00428/full}}</ref> #Avoiding any damage to [[water quality]]. #Improving [[water management]] practices that reduce the use or enhance the beneficial use of water.<ref name="Vickers, Amy 2002">{{cite book |title=Water Use and Conservation |last=Vickers |first=Amy |authorlink= |year=2002 |publisher= water plow Press |location=Amherst, MA |isbn=1-931579-07-5 |page=434 |url= |accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Geerts | first1 = S. | last2 = Raes | first2 = D. | year = 2009 | title = Deficit irrigation as an on-farm strategy to maximize crop water productivity in dry areas | doi = 10.1016/j.agwat.2009.04.009 | journal = Agric. Water Manage | volume = 96 | issue = 9| pages = 1275–1284 }}</ref> One strategy in water conservation is [[rain water harvesting]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Kumar Kurunthachalam|first=Senthil|year=2014|title=Water Conservation and Sustainability: An Utmost Importance.|url=|journal=Hydrol Current Res|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Digging ponds, lakes, canals, expanding the water reservoir, and installing rain water catching ducts and filtration systems on homes are different methods of harvesting rain water. Many people in many countries keep clean containers so they can boil it and drink it, which is useful to supply water to the needy.<ref name=":12" /> Harvested and filtered rain water can be used for toilets, home gardening, lawn irrigation, and small scale agriculture.<ref name=":12" />
Another strategy in water conservation is protecting [[groundwater]] resources. When precipitation occurs, some infiltrates the soil and goes underground.<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nwrfc.noaa.gov/info/water_cycle/hydrology.cgi|title=Description of the Hydrologic Cycle|last=|first=|date=|website=nwrfc.noaa.gov/rfc/|publisher=NOAA River Forecast Center|access-date=}}</ref> Water in this saturation zone is called groundwater.<ref name=":22" /> [[groundwater contamination|Contamination of groundwater]] causes the groundwater water supply to not be able to be used as resource of fresh drinking water and the natural regeneration of contaminated groundwater can takes years to replenish.<ref name=":32">{{Cite web|url=http://www.groundwater.org/get-informed/groundwater/contamination.html|title=Potential threats to Groundwater|last=|first=|date=|website=groundwater.org/|publisher=The Groundwater Foundation|access-date=}}</ref> Some examples of potential sources of groundwater contamination include storage tanks, [[septic tank|septic]] systems, uncontrolled [[hazardous waste]], [[landfill]]s, [[atmospheric contaminants]], chemicals, and [[road salt]]s.<ref name=":32" /> Contamination of groundwater decreases the replenishment of available freshwater so taking preventative measures by protecting groundwater resources from contamination is an important aspect of water conservation.<ref name=":12" />
An additional strategy to water conservation is practicing sustainable methods of utilizing groundwater resources.<ref name=":12" /> Groundwater flows due to gravity and eventually discharges into streams.<ref name=":22" /> Excess pumping of groundwater leads to a decrease in groundwater levels and if continued it can exhaust the resource.<ref name=":12" /> Ground and surface waters are connected and overuse of groundwater can reduce and, in extreme examples, diminish the water supply of lakes, rivers, and streams.<ref name=":32" /> In coastal regions, over pumping groundwater can increase saltwater intrusion which results in the contamination of groundwater water supply.<ref name=":32" /> Sustainable use of groundwater is essential in water conservation.
A fundamental component to water conservation strategy is communication and education outreach of different water programs.<ref name=":02">{{cite journal|last1=Delgado|first1=Jorge A.|last2=Groffman|first2=Peter M.|last3=Nearing|first3=Mark A.|last4=Goddard|first4=Tom|last5=Reicosky|first5=Don|last6=Lal|first6=Rattan|last7=Kitchen|first7=Newell R.|last8=Rice|first8=Charles W.|last9=Towery|first9=Dan|last10=Salon|first10=Paul|title=Conservation practices to mitigate and adapt to climate change|journal=Journal of Soil and Water Conservation|date=1 July 2011|volume=66|issue=4|pages=118A–129A|doi=10.2489/jswc.66.4.118A|url=http://www.jswconline.org/content/66/4/118A.refs|accessdate=25 May 2018|language=en|issn=0022-4561}}</ref> Developing communication that educates science to land managers, policy makers, farmers, and the general public is another important strategy utilized in water conservation.<ref name=":02" /> Communication of the science of how water systems work is an important aspect when creating a management plan to conserve that system and is often used for ensuring the right management plan to be put into action.<ref name=":02" />
== Social solutions == [[File:VineyardDrip.JPG|thumb|right|[[Drip irrigation]] system in [[New Mexico]]]] Water conservation programs involved in social solutions are typically initiated at the local level, by either municipal [[water industry|water utilities]] or regional governments. Common strategies include public [[outreach]] campaigns,<ref>[http://www.wateruseitwisely.com "Water - Use It Wisely."] U.S. multi-city public outreach program. Park & Co., Phoenix, AZ. Accessed 2010-02-02.</ref> tiered water rates (charging progressively higher prices as water use increases), or restrictions on outdoor water use such as lawn watering and car washing.<ref>{{Cite report |title=Cases in Water Conservation |url=http://www.epa.gov/watersense/docs/utilityconservation_508.pdf |author=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) |year=2002 |accessdate=2010-02-02}} Document No. EPA-832-B-02-003.</ref> Cities in dry climates often require or encourage the installation of [[xeriscaping]] or [[natural landscaping]] in new homes to reduce outdoor water usage.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abcwua.org/content/view/132/222/ |title= Xeriscape Rebates |author= Albuquerque Bernalillo County Water Utility Authority |authorlink= |date= 2009-02-06 |work= |location=Albuquerque, NM |accessdate= 2010-02-02}}</ref> Most urban outdoor water use in California is residential,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heberger|first=Matthew|year=2014|title=Issue Brief|url=http://pacinst.org/app/uploads/2014/06/ca-water-urban.pdf|journal=Urban Water Conservation and efficiency Potential in California|volume=|pages=12|via=}}</ref> illustrating a reason for outreach to households as well as businesses.
One fundamental conservation goal is universal metering. The prevalence of residential [[water meter]]ing varies significantly worldwide. Recent studies have estimated that water supplies are metered in less than 30% of UK households,<ref>[http://www.innovations-report.com/html/reports/environment_sciences/report-60279.html "Time for universal water metering?"] ''Innovations Report.'' May 2006.</ref> and about 61% of urban Canadian homes (as of 2001).<ref>{{Cite report |title=Municipal Water Use, 2001 Statistics |url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/water-apps/en/info/pubs/sss/e_mun2001.pdf |author=Environment Canada |year=2005 |accessdate=2010-02-02}} Cat. No. En11-2/2001E-PDF. {{ISBN|0-662-39504-2}}. p. 3.</ref> Although individual water meters have often been considered impractical in homes with private wells or in multifamily buildings, the U.S. [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] estimates that metering alone can reduce consumption by 20 to 40 percent.<ref name="EPA-Conserve">{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/owow/nps/nps-conserve.html |title=How to Conserve Water and Use It Effectively |author=EPA |date=2010-01-13 |work= |location=Washington, DC|accessdate=2010-02-03}}</ref> In addition to raising consumer awareness of their water use, metering is also an important way to identify and localize [[water leakage]]. Water metering would benefit society, in the long run, it is proven that water metering increases the efficiency of the entire water system, as well as help unnecessary expenses for individuals for years to come. One would be unable to waste water unless they are willing to pay the extra charges, this way the water department would be able to monitor water usage by the public, domestic and manufacturing services.
Some researchers have suggested that water conservation efforts should be primarily directed at farmers, in light of the fact that crop irrigation accounts for 70% of the world's fresh water use.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Pimentel, Berger|title=Water resources: agricultural and environmental issues |journal=BioScience |volume=54 |issue=10 |pages=909 |date=October 2004 |doi=10.1641/0006-3568(2004)054[0909:WRAAEI]2.0.CO;2|display-authors=etal }}</ref> The agricultural sector of most countries is important both economically and politically, and water subsidies are common. Conservation advocates have urged removal of all subsidies to force [[farmers]] to grow more water-efficient crops and adopt less wasteful irrigation techniques.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
New technology poses a few new options for consumers, features such as full flush and half flush when using a toilet are trying to make a difference in water consumption and waste. Also available are modern [[shower head]]s that help reduce wasting water: Old shower heads are said to use 5-10 gallons per minute, while new fixtures available are said to use 2.5 gallons per minute and offer equal water coverage.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
== Household applications == The Home Water Works website contains useful information on household water conservation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.home-water-works.org|title=Water Usage Calculator, Water Conservation and Efficiency - Home Water Works|website=www.home-water-works.org}}</ref> Contrary to the popular view that the most effective way to save water is to curtail water-using behavior (e.g., by taking shorter showers),<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2014/02/26/1316402111|title=Perceptions of water use|first=Shahzeen Z.|last=Attari|date=26 February 2014|publisher=|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|pages=201316402|via=www.pnas.org|doi=10.1073/pnas.1316402111|pmid=24591608|pmc=3986180}}</ref> experts suggest the most efficient way is replacing toilets and retrofitting washers; as demonstrated by two [[Residential water use in the U.S. and Canada|household end use logging]] studies in the U.S.<ref>Mayer, P.W.; DeOreo, W.B.; Opitz, E.M.; Kiefer, J.C.; Davis, W.Y.; Dziegielewski, B.; & Nelson, J.O., 1999. Residential End Uses of Water. AWWARF and AWWA, Denver. http://www.waterrf.org/PublicReportLibrary/RFR90781_1999_241A.pdf</ref><ref name="REUW2">William B. DeOreo, Peter Mayer, Benedykt Dziegielewski, Jack Kiefer. 2016. Residential End Uses of Water, Version 2. [[Water Research Foundation]]. Denver, Colorado. http://www.waterrf.org/Pages/Projects.aspx?PID=4309</ref>
Water-saving technology for the home includes: #Low-flow shower heads sometimes called energy-efficient shower heads as they also use less energy #[[Low flush toilet|Low-flush toilet]]s and [[composting toilet]]s. These have a dramatic impact in the developed world, as conventional Western [[toilet]]s use large volumes of water #[[Dual flush toilet]]s created by [[Caroma]] includes two buttons or handles to flush different levels of water. Dual flush toilets use up to 67% less water than conventional toilets #[[Faucet aerator]]s, which break water flow into fine droplets to maintain "wetting effectiveness" while using less water. An additional benefit is that they reduce splashing while washing hands and dishes #[[Raw water flushing]] where toilets use sea water or non-purified water #[[Reclaimed water|Wastewater reuse]] or recycling systems, allowing: #*Reuse of [[greywater|graywater]] for flushing toilets or watering gardens #*Recycling of wastewater through [[water purification|purification]] at a water treatment plant. ''See also [[Wastewater#Reuse|Wastewater - Reuse]]'' #[[Rainwater harvesting]] #High-efficiency [[washing machine|clothes washer]]s #Weather-based irrigation controllers #[[Garden hose]] [[nozzle]]s that shut off the water when it is not being used, instead of letting a hose run. # Low flow taps in wash basins #[[Swimming pool]] covers that reduce evaporation and can warm pool water to reduce water, energy and chemical costs. #[[Automatic faucet]] is a water conservation faucet that eliminates water waste at the faucet. It automates the use of faucets without the use of hands.
== Commercial applications == Many water-saving devices (such as low-flush toilets) that are useful in homes can also be useful for business water saving. Other water-saving technology for businesses includes: *[[Waterless urinal]]s *[[Waterless car wash]]es *[[Infrared]] or foot-operated taps, which can save water by using short bursts of water for rinsing in a kitchen or bathroom *Pressurized waterbrooms, which can be used instead of a hose to clean sidewalks *[[Radiography|X-ray]] film processor re-circulation systems *[[Cooling tower]] conductivity controllers *Water-saving [[steam sterilizer]]s, for use in hospitals and health care facilities *[[Rain water harvesting]] *Water to Water [[heat exchanger]]s.
== Agricultural applications == [[Image:PivotIrrigationOnCotton.jpg|thumb|216px|right|Overhead irrigation, [[Center pivot irrigation|center pivot]] design]] For crop irrigation, optimal [[water efficiency]] means minimizing losses due to [[evaporation]], [[Surface runoff|runoff]] or subsurface drainage while maximizing production. An [[evaporation pan]] in combination with specific crop correction factors can be used to determine how much water is needed to satisfy plant requirements. [[surface irrigation|Flood irrigation]], the oldest and most common type, is often very uneven in distribution, as parts of a field may receive excess water in order to deliver sufficient quantities to other parts. [[Irrigation#Overhead (sprinkler) irrigation|Overhead irrigation]], using center-pivot or lateral-moving sprinklers, has the potential for a much more equal and controlled distribution pattern. [[Drip irrigation]] is the most expensive and least-used type, but offers the ability to deliver water to plant roots with minimal losses. However, drip irrigation is increasingly affordable, especially for the home gardener and in light of rising water rates. Using drip irrigation methods can save up to 30,000 gallons of water per year when replacing irrigation systems that spray in all directions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www3.epa.gov/watersense/outdoor/tech.html|title=Water-Saving Technologies|last=|first=|date=|website=WaterSense: An EPA Partnership Program|publisher=US Environmental Protection Agency|access-date=}}</ref> There are also cheap effective methods similar to drip irrigation such as the use of soaking hoses that can even be submerged in the growing medium to eliminate evaporation.
As changing irrigation systems can be a costly undertaking, conservation efforts often concentrate on maximizing the efficiency of the existing system. This may include chiseling compacted soils, creating furrow dikes to prevent runoff, and using soil moisture and rainfall sensors to optimize irrigation schedules.<ref name="EPA-Conserve"/> Usually large gains in efficiency are possible through measurement and more effective management of the existing irrigation system. The 2011 UNEP Green Economy Report notes that "[i]mproved [[soil organic matter]] from the use of green manures, mulching, and recycling of crop residues and animal manure increases the water holding capacity of soils and their ability to absorb water during torrential rains",<ref>UNEP, 2011, Towards a Green Economy: Pathways to Sustainable Development and Poverty Eradication, www.unep.org/greeneconomy</ref> which is a way to optimize the use of rainfall and irrigation during dry periods in the season.
== Water Reuse == Water shortage has become an increasingly difficult problem to manage. More than 40% of the world's population live in a region where the demand for water exceeds its supply. The imbalance between supply and demand, along with persisting issues such as climate change and exponential [[population growth]], has made water reuse a necessary method for conserving water.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-3-319-23892-0|title=Wastewater Reuse and Current Challenges - Springer|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-23892-0}}</ref> There are a variety of methods used in the [[Water treatment|treatment of waste water]] to ensure that it is safe to use for irrigation of food crops and/or drinking water.
Seawater desalination requires more energy than the desalination of fresh water. Despite this, many seawater desalination plants have been built in response to water shortages around the world. This makes it necessary to evaluate the impacts of seawater desalination and to find ways to improve desalination technology. Current research involves the use of experiments to determine the most effective and least energy intensive methods of desalination.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Elimelech|first=Menachem|last2=Phillip|first2=William A.|date=2011-08-05|title=The Future of Seawater Desalination: Energy, Technology, and the Environment|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/333/6043/712|journal=Science|language=en|volume=333|issue=6043|pages=712–717|doi=10.1126/science.1200488|issn=0036-8075|pmid=21817042}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Han|first=Songlee|last2=Rhee|first2=Young-Woo|last3=Kang|first3=Seong-Pil|date=2017-02-17|title=Investigation of salt removal using cyclopentane hydrate formation and washing treatment for seawater desalination|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916416309742|journal=Desalination|volume=404|pages=132–137|doi=10.1016/j.desal.2016.11.016}}</ref>
[[Sand filter|Sand filtration]] is another method used to treat water. Recent studies show that sand filtration needs further improvements, but it is approaching optimization with its effectiveness at removing pathogens from water.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Seeger|first=Eva M.|last2=Braeckevelt|first2=Mareike|last3=Reiche|first3=Nils|last4=Müller|first4=Jochen A.|last5=Kästner|first5=Matthias|date=2016-10-01|title=Removal of pathogen indicators from secondary effluent using slow sand filtration: Optimization approaches|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0925857416303937|journal=Ecological Engineering|volume=95|pages=635–644|doi=10.1016/j.ecoleng.2016.06.068}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Vries|first=D.|last2=Bertelkamp|first2=C.|last3=Kegel|first3=F. Schoonenberg|last4=Hofs|first4=B.|last5=Dusseldorp|first5=J.|last6=Bruins|first6=J. H.|last7=de Vet|first7=W.|last8=van den Akker|first8=B.|title=Iron and manganese removal: Recent advances in modelling treatment efficiency by rapid sand filtration|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0043135416308703|journal=Water Research|volume=109|pages=35–45|doi=10.1016/j.watres.2016.11.032|pmid=27865171|year=2017}}</ref> Sand filtration is very effective at removing protozoa and bacteria, but struggles with removing viruses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/safewater/sand-filtration.html|title=Slow Sand Filtration|last=|first=|date=May 2, 2014|website=CDC.gov|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Large-scale sand filtration facilities also require large surface areas to accommodate them.
The removal of [[pathogen]]s from recycled water is of high priority because wastewater always contains pathogens capable of infecting humans. The levels of pathogenic viruses have to be reduced to a certain level in order for recycled water to not pose a threat to human populations. Further research is necessary to determine more accurate methods of assessing the level of pathogenic viruses in treated wastewater.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gerba|first=Charles P.|last2=Betancourt|first2=Walter Q.|last3=Kitajima|first3=Masaaki|title=How much reduction of virus is needed for recycled water: A continuous changing need for assessment?|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S004313541630865X|journal=Water Research|volume=108|pages=25–31|doi=10.1016/j.watres.2016.11.020|pmid=27838026|year=2017}}</ref>
== Wasting of water == [[File:Leaking garden hose bib.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|Leaking garden hose bib]] Wasting of water (also called "water waste" in the U.S.) is the flip side of water conservation and, in household applications, it means causing or permitting discharge of water without any practical purpose. Inefficient water use is also considered wasteful. By [[EPA]] estimate, household leaks in the U.S. can waste approximately 900 billion gallons (3.4 billion cubic meters) of water annually nationwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/watersense/statistics-and-facts |title=Statistics and Facts &#124; WaterSense &#124; US EPA |website=Epa.gov |date= |accessdate=2017-07-11}}</ref> Generally, water management agencies are reluctant or unwilling to give a concrete definition to the somewhat fuzzy concept of '''water waste'''.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://nationalaglawcenter.org/wp-content/uploads/assets/bibarticles/neuman_forfeiture.pdf |title=Janet C. Neuman. Beneficial Use, Waste, and Forfeiture:The Inefficient Search for Efficiency in Western Water Use |date= |accessdate=2017-08-06}}</ref> However, definition of water waste is often given in local drought emergency ordinances. One example refers to any acts or omissions, whether willful or negligent, that are “causing or permitting water to leak, discharge, flow or run to waste into any gutter, sanitary sewer, watercourse or public or private storm drain, or to any adjacent property, from any tap, hose, faucet, pipe, sprinkler, pond, pool, waterway, fountain or nozzle.”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://qcode.us/codes/roseville/view.php?topic=14-14_09-14_09_030&frames=off |title=14.09.030 Definition of water waste |website=Qcode.us |date= |accessdate=2017-07-11}}</ref> In this example, the city code also clarifies that “in the case of washing, “discharge,” “flow” or “run to waste” means that water in excess of that necessary to wash, wet or clean the dirty or dusty object, such as an automobile, sidewalk, or parking area, flows to waste. Water utilities (and other media sources) often provide listings of wasteful water-use practices and prohibitions of wasteful uses. Examples include utilities in San Antonio, Texas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saws.org/conservation/waterwaste/whatiswaste.cfm |title=SAWS Report Water Waste - What is Water Waste? |website=Saws.org |date= |accessdate=2017-07-11}}</ref> Las Vegas, Nevada,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lvvwd.com/conservation/waste.html |title=Water Waste |website=Lvvwd.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-11}}</ref> California Water Service company in California,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.calwater.com/conservation/water-waste-report/ |title=Report Water Waste |publisher=Cal Water |date=2015-12-03 |accessdate=2017-07-11}}</ref> and City of San Diego, California.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sandiego.gov/water/conservation/kids/tips |title=Water Saving Tips | City of San Diego Official Website |website=Sandiego.gov |date= |accessdate=2017-07-11}}</ref> The City of Palo Alto in California enforces permanent water use restrictions on wasteful practices such as leaks, runoff, irrigating during and immediately after rainfall, and use of potable water when non-potable water is available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cityofpaloalto.org/news/displaynews.asp?NewsID=2336&TargetID=235,310 |title=Water & Drought Update - Palo Alto Water Use Guidelines |date= |accessdate=2017-08-06}}</ref> Similar restrictions are in effect in the State of Victoria, Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.water.vic.gov.au/liveable-cities-and-towns/permanent-water-saving-rules |title=Permanent water saving rules |date= |accessdate=2017-08-06}}</ref> Temporary water use bans (also known as "hosepipe bans") are used in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.<ref>Water UK http://www.water.org.uk/consumers/tubs</ref>
Strictly speaking, water that is discharged into the sewer, or directly to the environment is not wasted or lost. It remains within the [[hydrologic cycle]] and returns to the land surface and surface water bodies as precipitation. However, in many cases, the source of the water is at a significant distance from the return point and may be in a different catchment. The separation between extraction point and return point can represent significant environmental degradation in the watercourse and riparian strip. What is "wasted" is the community's supply of water that was captured, stored, transported and treated to drinking quality standards. Efficient use of water saves the expense of water supply provision and leaves more fresh water in lakes, rivers and aquifers for other users and also for supporting ecosystems. A concept that is closely related to water wasting is "water-use efficiency." Water use is considered [[inefficiency|inefficient]] if the same purpose of its use can be accomplished with less water. Technical [[efficiency]] derives from engineering practice where it is typically used to describe the ratio of output to input and is useful in comparing various products and processes.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Dziegielewski, B. J.|author2=Kiefer, C.|title=Water Conservation Measurement Metrics: Guidance Report|journal=American Water Works Association|date=January 22, 2010|url=https://www.awwa.org/Portals/0/files/resources/resource%20dev%20groups/tech%20and%20educ%20program/documents/WaterConservationMeasurementMetricsGuidanceReport.pdf}}</ref> For example, one showerhead would be considered more efficient than another if it could accomplish the same purpose (i.e., of showering) by using less water or other inputs (e.g., lower water pressure). However, the technical efficiency concept is not useful in making decisions of investing money (or resources) in water conservation measures unless the inputs and outputs are measured in value terms. This expression of efficiency is referred to as [[economic efficiency]] and is incorporated into the concept of water conservation.
